awd_titl_txt: Diol-Mediated Benzannulation for Polyaromatic Hydrocarbon (PAH) Construction
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Michael J. Krische of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Texas at Austin is applying catalytic reactions developed in his laboratory to the construction of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons are used in commercial electronic display screens and show promise in a range of other applications, for example, high-speed electronics and solar cells. The project involves expertise spanning the fields of organic chemistry, homogenous transition metal catalysis, and materials chemistry.  Professor Krische mentors and trains undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral research associates, including students from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences.  Professor Krische founded and continues to co-organize a state-wide organic chemistry symposium in Texas, known as ?TEXSYN.? This annual event, which attracts >100 attendees, includes a poster session and short talks by undergraduate and graduate students, connecting students with leading researchers to design new routes to commodity and fine chemicals. 

Professor Michael J. Krische's laboratory has pioneered a new class of catalytic carbon carbon bond formations that directly convert lower alcohols to higher alcohols. These processes bypass the use of stoichiometric metals and discrete alcohol-to-carbonyl redox reactions, which are hazardous and contribute to waste generation. Based on this new reactivity pattern, diol-mediated benzannulation reactions were developed. Under the aegis of NSF support, this benzannulation methodology will be used to advance new strategies for the synthesis of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and related nanographene materials, which are of significant importance in the growing field of molecular electronics. Whereas the field of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon synthesis is largely reliant on cross-coupling technology, this diol-mediated benzannulations could unlock broad and new polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon chemical space.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The University of Texas at Austin

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes (NSF-CHE-1855744): ?Diol-Mediated Benzannulation for PAH Construction? 

 

Background and Scientific Impacts: The formation of carbon-carbon (C-C) bonds underlies the preparation of diverse materials, medicines and agrochemicals. Professor Krische has pioneered a broad, new family of catalytic C-C bond formations that occur through the addition or redistribution of hydrogen, the most abundant element in the universe. These processes merge the characteristics of hydrogenation and carbonyl addition, allowing inexpensive unsaturated hydrocarbons to serve as alternatives to hazardous/pyrophoric organometallic reagents, minimizing waste, cost and risk. Professor Krische?s innovative work has garnered numerous national and international awards, most recently through his receipt of the 2020 ACS Award for Creativity in Synthetic Organic Chemistry.

 

Under the aegis of NSF support, concepts for catalysis developed by Professor Krische were used to advance new methods for the construction of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) - an emerging class of materials with applications that range from solar energy conversion and molecular electronics to strong/lightweight structural materials. Despite their promise, methods for the manufacture of PAH's (including carbon nano-allotropes) have remained largely unchanged since the advent of biaryl cross-coupling, a Nobel prize-winning technology for C-C bond formation. Professor Krische?s new catalytic methods for PAH construction are unlocking new volumes of PAH chemical space, and fueling research beyond his own laboratory. The work accomplished under the aegis of NSF-CHE-1855744 has been presented in 27 invited seminars at academic and industrial venues in the USA and abroad and has been recorded in the scientific literature, as illustrated by the following publications that appear in top tier chemistry journals.

 

  • "Benzannulation via Ruthenium(0)-Catalyzed Transfer Hydrogenative Cycloaddition: Precision Synthesis and Photophysical Characterization of Soluble Diindenoperylenes," Suravarapu, S. R.; Parvathaneni, S. P.; Bender, J. A.; Roberts, S. T.; Krische, M. J. Chem. Eur. J. 2020, 26, 7504.

 

  • "Synthesis and Photophysical Properties of Soluble N-Doped Rubicenes via Ruthenium-Catalyzed Transfer Hydrogenative Benzannulation," Shuler, W. G.; Parvathaneni, S. P.; Rodriguez, J. B.; Lewis, T. N.; Nguyen, A.; Bardeen, C. J.; Krische, M. J. Chem. Eur. J. 2021, 27, 4898.

 

  • "Ruthenium-Catalyzed Cycloaddition to Form 5-, 6-, and 7-Membered Rings," Doerksen, R. S.; Hodik, T.; Hu, G.; Huynh, N. O.; Shuler, W. G.; Krische, M. J. Chem. Rev. 2021, 121, 4045.

 

  • "Chemical Tuning of Exciton versus Charge-Transfer Excited States in Conformationally Restricted Arylene Cages," Lewis, T. N.; Tonnel?, C.; Shuler, W. G.; Kasun, Z. A.; Sato, H.; Berges, A. J.; Rodriguez, J. B.; Krische, M. J.; Casanova, D.; Bardeen, C. J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2021, 143, 18548.

 

Broader Impacts: Women continue to be underrepresented in the field of chemical research. To offer career development training to female chemistry students at UT Austin and beyond, the "Women in Catalysis and Synthetic Chemistry" symposium was held (see attached flier). Professor Krische was the primary fund-raiser and organizer of this event, which attracted 134 in-person student attendees from 6 different universities across the state of Texas. There were also 25 virtual participants from 16 institutions around the world. The symposium featured the following activities: (a) Seminars by 5 leading female researchers from academia/industry; (b) "Speed Talks" by 5 female graduate students from across the state of Texas; (c) A poster session with 20 participants; (d) A career mentorship roundtable discussion between academic/industrial representatives and female chemistry students. 

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2023
Modified by: Michael J Krische

    Women in Chemistry Symposium
